rev.diff:
Line 4: Line 4:
Xcopilot found a new role in the 2000s with the development of [[uCLinux]], a version of Linux meant for very low-end microprocessors without an [[Memory management unit|MMU]] . Today Xcopilot is no longer maintained but is still useful for trying out uClinux. With the addition of a virtual ethernet Xcopilot would probably become more popular again, because the simulated hardware would then look very like many modern firewall and VPN devices based on Motorola processors. Networking is only available over [[Point-to-Point Protocol|PPP]] on the simulated serial port.
Xcopilot found a new role in the 2000s with the development of [[uCLinux]], a version of Linux meant for very low-end microprocessors without an [[Memory management unit|MMU]] . Today Xcopilot is no longer maintained but is still useful for trying out uClinux. With the addition of a virtual ethernet Xcopilot would probably become more popular again, because the simulated hardware would then look very like many modern firewall and VPN devices based on Motorola processors. Networking is only available over [[Point-to-Point Protocol|PPP]] on the simulated serial port.
â
At [[linux.conf.au | linux.conf.au 2004]] a [[LiveCD]] was produced <ref> The image was made by [http://shearer.org/User:Dan Dan Shearer] with the help of a team of testers and contributors</ref> to support the talks, one of which was on uCLinux <ref>The talk was given by [http://www.kernel-traffic.org/kernel-traffic/quotes/Greg_Ungerer.html Greg Ungerer] </ref>. The screenshot shows Xcopilot used on this CD to run a webserver explaining how to use the CD.
+
At [[linux.conf.au | linux.conf.au 2004]] a [[Live CD]] was produced <ref> The image was made by [http://shearer.org/User:Dan Dan Shearer] with the help of a team of testers and contributors</ref> to support the talks, one of which was on uCLinux <ref>The talk was given by [http://www.kernel-traffic.org/kernel-traffic/quotes/Greg_Ungerer.html Greg Ungerer] </ref>. The screenshot shows Xcopilot used on this CD to run a webserver explaining how to use the CD.
